title-group.article-title: Experimental justification on thermal empirical equations for post-flashover compartment fires

contrib-group.aff: Department of Building Services Engineering, Research Centre for Fire Engineering, The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong, China

author-notes.corresp: Wan-Ki Chow, Department of Building Services Engineering, Research Centre for Fire Engineering, The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hung Hom, Kowloon, Hong Kong, China. Email: bewkchow@polyu.edu.hk

abstract.p: Many useful correlation equations derived for estimating the heat release rate for a postflashover room fire were applied in performance-based design. A postflashover room fire is very hazardous as demonstrated by several big accidents in the past few years. The authorities are starting to challenge the use of such equations as fire engineering design tools. Additional justification of the results with experiments in fire hazard assessment is now required. Two correlation equations on heat release rates with gas temperature for postflashover fire are commonly used. One was reported by Babrauskas and Williamson and the other by McCaffrey et al., denoted as BW and MQH equations, respectively. Both equations were justified in this article by reported experimental data. Two sets of reported experimental results on postflashover room fires with transient heat release rates measured by oxygen consumption calorimetry were used. One set was reported by Chow et al. on studying flashover in a compartment fire with gasoline pool fires up to 2.8 MW. The other set was the experimental data on cable fires in a long cavity reported by Hietaniemi et al. Direct comparison indicated that heat release rates estimated using the BW equation are lower than measured values of both sets of the experiments. This point should be watched while applying the BW equation in fire hazard assessment. Better agreement was observed in the equation by MQH. A possible reason is that the empirical constants in the MQH equation were deduced by fitting with experimental data.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Fire hazard assessment is a key element in performance-based design (PBD) (e.g. Ref. 1) for providing appropriate fire safety in buildings. The possible heat release rate was commonly estimated by correlation equations to determine the available safe egress time (ASET). Fire engineers used to show that the heat release rate in a normal room fire is low, say lower than 2.5 MW in many projects, except on sizing areas in a natural venting system. There are many PBD projects with ASET estimated from such small design fires computed from the empirical expressions. Fire safety provisions are then determined and submitted for approval.2 However, several big postflashover building fires were observed in big cities in the Far East including one in Hong Kong in March 2010, one in Shanghai in the summer of 2010, and one in Shenyang in February 2011. Very high fire load density was observed in small residential units and offices in tall buildings. Consequently, there are concerns that the fire safety provisions are not adequate as experienced in fighting against such big fires.

Studies on the flashover phenomenon reported in the literature were mainly based on estimating airflow rate across an opening in the room fire. These included pioneer studies by Kawagoe3 on hydrostatic models to give a relation with ventilation factor. Many other studies followed4–13 with experimental data reported in the literature on deriving, assessing, or verifying such useful design empirical equations. Although there had been many studies on flashover fire, the understanding is still limited to thermal aspects. This is because, first, there are thousands of intermediate combustion chemical reactions while burning the fuel. Second, turbulent flow in air mixing is difficult to model. Third, thermal radiation heat fluxes cannot be calculated accurately without measuring empirical parameters. In those studies, heat release rate used to be assessed by the fuel mass loss rate. Flashover was commonly determined by observing whether flame came out of the doors. Results might be different if the heat release rates are measured by oxygen consumption calorimetry (e.g. Ref. 14).

Two empirical equations relating room fire temperature and heat release rate for postflashover fires are commonly used in PBD projects. One was derived by Babrauskas and Williamson5,8 denoted as the BW equation in this article. The other was derived by McCaffrey et al.10 denoted as the MQH equation. Both will be justified in this article using experimental results reported for postflashover fires. The first set of full-scale burning tests was on flashover in compartment fires with heat release rate measured by oxygen consumption calorimetry reported by Chow et al.15 Correlation equations on the minimum heat release rates for flashover with the ventilation factor5,7–13 had been justified by this set of full-scale burning tests. The second set of reported experimental data16 was on studying cable fires in a long cavity. Transient gas temperatures measured at different locations of the room in these two sets of tests will be used to estimate the transient heat release rate. Results are then compared with the heat release rates measured in the postflashover room fire.

where ‘a’ is given by
Thermal penetration time tp (s) is defined in terms of density ρw (kg m−3), specific heat cw (kJ kg−1 K−1), thermal conductivity kw (kW m−1 K−1), and thickness δw (m) of the wall surface material
The effective heat transfer coefficient through ceiling and walls hw is related to the exposure time t (s) when the time of exposure is less than the penetration time as
The variables are density ρw, specific heat cw, and thermal conductivity kw of the wall surface material as before.

sec.title: The simplified VB equation
sec.p:
The heat lost term
q
·
L
in the BW equation given by equation (1) might not be constant. Another approximate simplified method to determine fire temperature Tf was suggested by Babrauskas in 1981.16 Tf is related to a baseline temperature T* (°C), To, and five factors on burning rate stoichiometry factor θ1, equivalence ratio ϕ, wall steady-state loss factor θ2, wall transient loss factor θ3, opening height effect factor θ4, and combustion efficiency factor θ5 by
The burning rate stoichiometry factor θ1 can be expressed as an equivalence ratio ϕ, and for ϕ < 1

The wall transient loss factor θ3 is expressed in terms of Vf, Aw, exposure time t, ρw, cw, and kw of the wall material
At steady state, the wall transient losses factor θ3 is taken to be 1.
The opening height effect factor θ4 is related to hv
The combustion efficiency factor θ5 is related to maximum combustion efficiency bp

sec.title: Full-scale burning tests
sec.p: Experiments on postflashover fires were reported.15 A room calorimeter of length, width, and height of 3.6, 2.4, and 2.4 m, respectively, as shown in Figure 1, was constructed. Ventilation factor Vf was adjusted by a door with fixed width Wv (m) of 0.8 m but height hv varying from 0.9 to 1.95 m. Six sets of tests, labeled A1–A6, were carried out with different opening arrangements as shown in Figure 2. The values of Vf were from 0.68 to 2.18 m5/2 as shown in Table 1.

caption.p: Room calorimeter by Chow et al.15
Opening arrangement from Chow et al.15: (a) test A1, (b) test A2, (c) test A3, (d) test A4, (e) test A5, and (f) test A6.
Justification of BW equation using data by Chow et al.15

tr.td: Height of vent bottom above floor (m)

Maximum heat release rate measured,
q
·
max
(kW)

sec.p: A pool fire of 1 m diameter and 1.5 L gasoline was placed at the room center. The burning period tB (s) varied from 422 to 621 s for the six tests. Air temperature To of the experimental hall varied from 15°C to 16°C.

Transient gas temperatures Tfs were measured by seven thermocouples at positions T1–T4 as shown in Figure 1. There was one thermocouple each at T1, T2, and T3, and four thermocouples labeled T4a–T4d at T4. Measured gas temperature profiles Tf for the seven thermocouples are shown in Figure 3. Transient heat release rates
q
·
in the room fire were measured by the oxygen consumption method with results as shown in Figure 4.

caption.p: Measured gas temperatures reported by Chow et al.15: (a) test A1a, (b) test A1b, (c) test A2a, (d) test A2b, (e) test A3a, (f) test A3b, (g) test A4a, (h) test A4b, (i) test A5a, (j) test A5b, and (k) test A6.
Transient heat release rates reported by Chow et al.15

sec.p:
Flashover was determined by two criteria: gas temperature next to the ceiling reaching 600°C and radiative heat flux reaching 20 kW m−2 at the floor. It was confirmed by watching whether there were any flames coming out of the opening. The time required for gas temperature next to the ceiling to reach 600°C, tT (s), and time required for the radiative heat flux to reach 20 kW m−2, tR (s), were recorded. From the transient curve on
q
·
, the minimum heat release rates for flashover
q
mf
·
were then taken out from the values of
q
·
at tT and tR. Results are shown in Table 1.

Two tests on burning cables with plastic polyethylene (PE) sheathing in a long cavity at VTT Technical Research Centre of Finland (VTT) were reported.17 The cavity was 6 m in length, 1.2 m in width, and 0.6 m in height, as shown in Figure 5. The cables had a diameter of 28 mm and a length of 6 m. These two tests were labeled V1 on 6 PE-sheathed cables and V2 on 10 PE-sheathed cables, respectively, in this article. Transient gas temperatures Tf were measured by five thermocouples at positions G2–G5 as shown in Figure 5. A burner was positioned under the 50-cm cables from one end of the cavity. The smoke generated in the burning was collected at the other end of the cavity by a steel pipe.

caption.p: Long cavity by Hietaniemi et al.17

sec.p: The cables were ignited by the burner operating to give out thermal power of 50 kW. After ignition, the burner was turned off and removed from the cavity. Transient heat release rates measured by oxygen consumption and gas temperatures recorded are processed in a similar way as mentioned previously. These two tests have different values of Av, Hv, Aw, Tf, and To as shown in Table 2. For both tests V1 and V2, Vf was 0.39 m5/2 as shown in Table 3. Values of mAV, mAL, and mA were estimated.

caption.p: Fitting MQH equation using data by Chow et al.15
Fitting results by Hietaniemi et al.17

sec.title: Fitting with experimental data by Chow et al.15
sec.p:
Transient experimental data on heat release rate
q
·
max
and the gas temperature rise (Tf− To) at all seven points at T1–T4 in the fire compartment reported by Chow et al.15 were analyzed in six ways to compare the results of different stages of the fire.

list-item.p: Values of maximum heat release rate were plotted against the maximum temperature rise.

Transient values of
q
·
and (Tf− To) were analyzed only at the thermocouple points with the maximum gas temperature Tfmax recorded.

Transient values of all data on
q
·
and (Tf− To) were studied to investigate the range of measured values of (Tf− To) recorded.
Only those gas temperatures Tf above 600°C upon flashover were used.
The gas temperatures Tf when the heat flux was above 20 kW m−2 were used.
Time required for the maximum heat release rate and time required for the maximum gas temperature were matched, and only gas temperature Tf over 600°C was used.

sec.p: Results of all six analyses are used to justify both the BW and MQH equations.

The BW equation was justified by putting numerical values of Cp of 1.05 kJ kg−1 K−1 and associated values of Vf in each test to equation (11). The six sets of tests have different values of Vf, Aw, Tf, and To to give different values of mAV, mAL, and mA. For example, if Vf is 2.18 m5/2 for test A1a, then mAV is 1.145 kW °C−1. Putting Aw of 44.52 m2, σ of 5.67 × 10−11 kW m−2 K−4, εf of 0.5, Tf of 1079 K, and T0 of 288 K for test A1a into equation (12) gives mAL of 0.86 kW °C−1. Substituting mAV and mAL into equation (10) gives mA of 2.00 kW °C−1. Results of mAV, mAL, and mA for the six sets of tests are estimated as shown in Table 1.

On the first analysis, values of maximum heat release rate
q
·
max
(kW) for the tests are plotted against the measured maximum gas temperature rise (Tfmax− To) among all seven points at T1–T4. The value of Tfmax (°C) was determined from the maximum value of all gas temperatures measured by the seven thermocouples. Maximum values for Tfmax were found at T4b for tests A1a–A5a and at T4a for tests A5b and A6 as reported earlier by Wu and Chow,18 justifying only the BW equation. A straight line of correlation coefficient R2 of 0.649 was fitted by the method of least square

Experimental data on
q
·
max
and (Tfmax− To) and the above line are shown in Figure 6. These values of mA estimated by thermal balance equation (10) varied from 0.84 kW °C−1 for test A6 with 30% stoichiometric burning F to 2.49 kW °C−1 for test A1b with 70% stoichiometric burning. It is clearly observed that experimental heat release rates measured by the oxygen consumption method are much higher than the estimated values.

caption.p: Maximum heat release rate against maximum gas temperature reported by Chow et al.15

sec.p: Values of mf (kW °C−1) and the corresponding correlation coefficient R2 for the six sets of tests are shown in Table 1. Values of mf are from 1.65 kW °C−1 for test A6 to 3.09 kW °C−1 for test A1a. These lines are plotted together with analytical results for each test given by equation (9) in Figure 7.

On the third analysis,
q
·
are also plotted against all gas temperatures measured at all seven thermocouples as shown in Figure 8. Values of mf for all data are also estimated with R2 as shown in Table 1. It is observed that values of mf range from 1.48 kW °C−1 for test A6 to 2.98 kW °C−1 for test A1a.

caption.p: Transient heat release rate with all gas temperatures reported by Chow et al.15: (a) test A1a, (b) test A1b, (c) test A2a, (d) test A2b, (e) test A3a, (f) test A3b, (g) test A4a, (h) test A4b, (i) test A5a, (j) test A5b, and (k) test A6.

sec.p:
On the fourth analysis, only the results with gas temperature over 600°C are plotted in Figure 9. The values of (Tf− To) for the resultant heat flow at flashover over 20 kW m−2 in the fifth analysis are plotted in Figure 10. Maximum
q
·
and maximum (Tf− To) with gas temperature over 600°C in the sixth analysis are plotted in Figure 11. Values of mf for all data are also estimated with R2 as shown in Table 1.

caption.p: Using only data with temperature over 600°C by Chow et al.15: (a) test A1a, (b) test A1b, (c) test A2a, (d) test A2b, (e) test A3a, (f) test A3b, (g) test A4a, (h) test A4b, (i) test A5a, (j) test A5b, and (k) test A6.

sec.p: On justifying the MQH equation by the tests reported by Chow et al.,15 wall made of brick of thickness δw is about 0.1 m. Values of ρw, cw, and kw are 2000 kg m−3, 0.84 kJ kg−1 K−1, and 1.32 × 10−3 kW m−1 K−1, respectively; and tp is estimated to be 3182 s. The burning time in these tests range from 422 to 621 s and is much shorter than the penetration time. The exposure time is taken as 300 s, and hw is estimated to be 0.086 kW m−2 K−1.

Putting numerical values of g of 9.8 m s−2, Cp of 1.05 kJ kg−1 K−1, ρo of 1.2 kg m−3, hw of 0.086 kW m−2 K−1, To of about 15°C, Aw of 44.52 m2, and Vf of 2.18 m5/2 for test A1a into equation (15), a is 0.16 kW °C−3/2. The following curve relating

Different values of a for the six sets of tests were estimated as shown in Table 2.
The following line fitted by the method of least square for each test with slope af (kW °C−2/3) is given as

Values of af and the corresponding correlation coefficient R2 for the six sets of tests are also shown in Table 2. Fitted lines on experimental data with MQH results given by equation (15) are included from Figures 6 to 11.

In using MQH equation, the estimated heat release rate at different gas temperature was higher than the experimental value. On justifying the simplified VB equation by the tests reported by Chow et al.,15 values of δw, kw, ρw, and cw of the wall material are found to be 0.1 m, 1.32 × 10−3 kW m−1 K−1, 2000 kg m−3, and 0.84 kJ kg−1 K−1, respectively. For test A1a, putting numerical values of Vf of 2.18 m5/2 and Aw of 44.52 m2 into equation (22), θ2 is estimated to be 0.96. Burning time is less than 650 s; hence,
t

is not in the range of 0.0005–0.02 K2 W−2, and the value of 0.63 is found to be a reasonable estimation for θ3. Putting numerical values of hv of 1.95 m into equation (24), θ4 is estimated to be 0.83. For equation (25), bp is taken to be 0.9 and θ5 is estimated to be 0.95. Putting numerical value of Vf of 2.18 m5/2 into equation (28), b is estimated to be 460 kW.
Substituting the values of θ2, θ3, θ4, and θ5 into equation (29) gives a c of 414°C. Results of b and c for the six sets of tests are estimated as shown in Table 1.

Different values of a in the MQH equation given by equation (15) for the two VTT tests were estimated as shown in Table 3. Values of af given by equation (33) in fitting data for justifying the MQH equation for the two VTT tests are also shown in Table 3. The corresponding correlation coefficient R2 are also shown. Fitted lines on experimental data with MQH results given by equation (15) are included in Figures 12 and 13. In using MQH equation, the estimated heat release rate at different gas temperatures was lower than the experimental value.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
Heat release rate measured by oxygen consumption calorimetry was related to the gas temperature by a thermal balance equation.5,8,10 Experimental results for both sets of tests are higher than the values estimated by the BW equation. It appears that the ventilation term on estimating heat release rate mAV(Tf− To) should be higher. The value of mA estimated by taking 70% of those required for stoichiometric reaction
q
s
·
would agree better with the measurement.
A factor β is proposed to modify mAV for estimating heat release rate at postflashover fire by the BW equation given by equations (9) and (10)

The following straight line can be fitted by experimental data as given in equation (31):
q
·
=
m
f
(

T
o
)
Therefore
where β is 1 when mf is same as the analytical value (mAV+ mAL). For test A1a, β is (2.98 − 0.86)/1.14 or 1.85 for the line fitting all data points on the seven thermocouples at T1–T4.

Values of β for the tests A1–A6 are shown in Table 1. All these values suggested that the burning rate due to ventilation across opening would be almost double the value of that computed by equation (3).

As reported5,8, value of
q
·
mf
is 50% of
q
·
s
, but lies between 30% and 70% of
q
·
s
. Using this argument, the term mAV due to ventilation provision would be varying from (0.3/0.5) to (0.7/0.5) of the value given by equation (11). The value of mA is then varying between (0.6 mAV+ mAL) and (1.4 mAV+ mAL). Values of mA for test A1a should be lying between 1.55 and 2.46 kW °C−1. The range of validity for mA given by equation (10) lying between (0.6 mAV+ mAL) and (1.4 mAV+ mAL) is estimated with examples from the second analysis (2) as shown in Tables 1 and 3 and plotted in Figures 7 to 13.
Results on all analyses are also shown in Table 1 and plotted in the figure.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Field surveys indicated that large amount of combustibles are stored in dense cities. Many postflashover big fires resulted from the burning up of such combustibles as observed. Taking Hong Kong2 as an example, most of the factories moved to China since the early 1980s. Very few big postflashover fires in factories were reported in the past 20 years. Small design fires were then accepted by some PBD projects. But there are more fire incidents in old factory buildings built 40 years ago. Possible reasons are, first, some factories for light plastics industry are starting to move back to Hong Kong. Second, such industrial buildings are now functioning as miniwarehouses. These old buildings used as storage areas will have much more combustibles but are not yet classified as warehouses. Appropriate fire protection systems are then not provided. Three big postflashover fires occurred had already killed four firemen in the past few years. Training in fighting against postflashover fires should be enhanced. Fire safety provisions in these industrial buildings must be upgraded. Flashover should be studied properly in PBD projects. Systematic full-scale burning tests should be carried out for better understanding of the fire response of new architectural features and modern materials. The heat release rate for flashover fires should be high while using as a design parameter.

The correlation BW5,8 and MQH10 equations on relating the heat release rates to gas temperature at postflashover fires were justified by two sets of full-scale burning tests at different ventilation factors. Heat release rates for flashover fires were studied experimentally with oxygen consumption calorimetry rather than by the mass loss rate.19

It is observed that the heat release rates estimated by the BW equation5,8 were lower than the two sets of experimental measurement reported.15,16 Heat release rate estimated by the MQH equation10 agreed better with experiments. This equation was derived by fitting experimental data under different conditions.

The BW equation derived from thermal balance should be physically correct. However, air intake rate might be higher to give more oxygen for combustion. Comparing with the experimental data reported earlier, burning rate due to ventilation across opening would be about double the value computed by equation (3). Air pumping action20,21 of fire plume should be considered in applying empirical correlation for estimating heat release rate.

sec.title: Nomenclature
sec.p: a Constant related to total heat release rate in MQH equation (kW °C−3/2)
af Slope of fitted line related to MQH equation (kW °C−3/2)
Av Area of ventilation opening (m2)
Aw Total wall area of compartment (m2)
b Constant related to total heat release rate in simplified VB equation (kW)
bp Maximum combustion efficiency
c Constant related to total heat release rate in simplified VB equation (°C)
cw Specific heat capacity of the wall material (kJ kg−1 K−1)
Cp Specific heat capacity of gas (kJ kg−1 K−1)
g Gravitational acceleration (m s−2)
hv Height of ventilation opening (m)
hw Effective heat transfer coefficient through ceiling and walls (kW m−2 K−1)
kw Thermal conductivity of wall material (kW m−1 K−1)

m
a
·
Airflow rate through the ventilation opening (kg s−1)
mf Slope of fitted line related to BW equation (kW °C−1)

m
p

Fuel mass loss rate (kg s−1)
mA Constant related to total heat release rate in BW equation (kW °C−1)
mAL Constant related to heat lost in BW equation (kW °C−1)
mAV Constant related to ventilation provision heat lost in BW equation (kW °C−1)

q
·
Heat release rate of fire (kW)

q
·

q

Minimum heat release rate for flashover (kW)

Stoichiometric heat release rate (kW)

q
·
L
Heat lost rate (kW)
R2 Correlation coefficient
t Exposure time (s)
tp Thermal penetration time (s)
tB Burning time of fuel (s)
tR Time for radiative heat flux to reach 20 kW m−2 (s)
tT Time for air temperature next to ceiling to reach 600°C (s)
Tf Fire temperature (°C)
Tfmax Maximum fire temperature measured (°C)
To Air temperature of hall (°C)
Vf Ventilation factor for ventilation opening (m5/2)
Wv Width of ventilation opening (m)
α Parameter related to the BW equation of minimum heat release rate for flashover (kW m−5/2)
β Factor to modify mAV in BW equation
Δhc Effective calorific value of fuel (kJ kg−1)
δw Wall surface thickness (m)
εf Gas emissivity
θ1 Burning rate stoichiometry factor in simplified VB equation
θ2 Wall steady-state losses factor in simplified VB equation
θ3 Wall transient losses factor in simplified VB equation
θ4 Opening height factor in simplified VB equation
θ5 Combustion efficiency factor in simplified VB equation
ρo Density of air at ambient temperature (kg m−3)
ρw Density of wall material (kg m−3)
σ Stefan–Boltzmann constant (kW m−2 K−4)
ϕ Equivalence ratio

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The study described in this article was supported by a grant from the Research Grants Council of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, China, for the project ‘Smoke Emission in Burning Fire Resisting Glass with Higher Rating’ (PolyU 5145/07E) with account number B-Q05q.

bio.title: Author biographies
bio.p: Miao Wu is a PhD degree research student at the Department of Building Services Engineering of The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hung Hom, Kowloon, Hong Kong, China, working under the supervision of Professor W K Chow.

Wan-Ki Chow is the Chair Professor of Architectural Science and Fire Engineering, Director of Research Centre for Fire Engineering, and Head of Department, Department of Building Services Engineering of The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hung Hom, Kowloon, Hong Kong, China. He is the Founding President of the Hong Kong Chapter, Society of Fire Protection Engineers, since 2002 and has been elected as the President of the Asia-Oceania Association for Fire Science and Technology in 2007.
